repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Democratic Republic of - Emergency
            Social Action Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Social Action
            Project for Congo, Democratic Republic of were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was substantial, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            the Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: actively engaging provincial and local
            government in the sub-project selection process at the
            provincial level is a good way to ensure that the
            sub-projects funded are considered priorities by both the
            beneficiary community and the relevant sector ministries and
            local government. This in turn helps to ensure that
            completed sub-projects are staffed and equipped by
            complementary government financing. Likewise, the national
            government must be required to make a match investment in
            the Social Fund, either by contributing public sector
            resources or by engaging with other donor or private sector
            companies to raise additional Social Fund capital. The lack
            of national government contributions undermines the
            long-term sustainability of the social fund, increasing the
            likelihood that it will cease to exist once World Bank
            funding ends. The DRC context requires investments in
            project management costs that exceed the Bank's
            standard ceiling of 20 percent of total budget costs. This
            will help project implementation units be better equipped to
            effectively support operations over a vast territory, where
            transport facilities are often expensive and precarious.
            Adequate funding needs to be allocated to monitoring and
            evaluation (M&E). Project indicators need to be very
            clearly defined, and project staff and partners need to be
            trained in a common methodology for gathering, recording,
            and documenting indicator data. To do this effectively,
            provincial offices need to have M&E specialists on
            staff. Data audits, carried out by an internal or third
            party auditor, are as important as financial audits in
            verifying that a project is on track in achieving project
            results transparently.

repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Democratic Republic of - Additional
            Financing for the Emergency Social Action Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Additional
            Financing for the Emergency Social Action Project for Congo,
            Democratic Republic of is to improve access of the poor to
            social and economic services and increase the availability
            and management of development resources at the community
            level. The closing date of the project will be extended from
            March 31, 2013 until June 30, 2013. The extension is
            necessary to compensate for some of the implementation delay
            caused by a World Bank request to change disbursement
            procedures (after six months, disbursement procedures were
            reverted to the original ones). In particular, the extension
            will make it possible to finalize the implementation of 175
            sub-projects, of which 125 financed by the first additional
            financing and 50 by the second additional financing. This
            will bring the total number of sub-projects completed under
            the first additional financing to 327 and the total number
            of sub-projects financed under the second additional
            financing to 58, equivalent to a disbursement of about USD
            10 million.

            Additional Financing for the Emergency Social Action Project

repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Democratic Republic of - Second
            Additional Financing for the Emergency Social Action Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Second
            Additional Financing for the Emergency Social Action Project
            for Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) is to improve access
            to social services by the poor and enhance management of
            development resources at the community level. Performance
            indicator targets have been updated to reflect the
            additional funds being made available. The additional grant
            will help finance the costs associated with scaling up
            successful activities of a well performing project that has
            led to substantial increase in access to basic social
            services. The activities to be funded comprise: (i)
            rehabilitation and construction of small-scale community
            based infrastructure; (ii) capacity building primarily for
            beneficiary communities and local executing agencies
            involved in project implementation; and (iii) project
            coordination and management. The additional financing will
            target communities in the Seke Banza territory in the
            Bas-Congo province.
